_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The four kinds of mindfulness meditation: Observing an aspect of the body
Observing an aspect of the mind
Steps in observing an aspect of the body: Sitting down cross-legged, with their body straight
Focusing their mindfulness on the body
Practicing breathing in experiencing the whole body
Practicing breathing out experiencing the whole body
Practicing breathing in stilling the body’s motion
Practicing breathing out stilling the body’s motion
Meditating observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally
Meditating observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish
Establishing mindfulness that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
Meditating independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
Knowing the posture of the body
Meditating observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally
Meditating observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish
Establishing mindfulness that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
Meditating independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
Situational Awareness [mn10:8.0]: Bearing the outer robe, bowl, and robes
Walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent
Steps in observing an aspect of the body: Meditating observing an aspect of the body internally
The charnel ground contemplations [mn10:: A corpse discarded in a charnel ground, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering
A corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures
A skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews
A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews
A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews
Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction
White bones, the color of shells
Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile
Bones rotted and crumbled to powder
The aspects of the body observed during: The body observed both internally and externally
The body observed as liable to originate
The body observed as liable to vanish
The body observed as liable to both originate and vanish
The mindfulness established during medit: Mindfulness established that the body exists
Mindfulness established to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
The meditation practice [mn10:14.0]: Meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
The aspects of feelings observed during: The feelings observed both internally and externally
The feelings observed as liable to originate
The feelings observed as liable to vanish
The feelings observed as liable to both originate and vanish
The mindfulness established during medit: Mindfulness established to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
The meditation practice [mn10:32.0]: Meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
The observations made during meditation: Understanding the presence or absence of each hindrance
Understanding how each hindrance is given up
Understanding how each hindrance does not arise again in the future
The meditation practice [mn10:34.0]: Meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally
Meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish
Mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
Meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
The observations made during meditation: Contemplating the nature of each grasping aggregate
Contemplating the origin of each grasping aggregate
Contemplating the ending of each grasping aggregate
The meditation practice [mn10:38.0]: Meditate observing an aspect of principles internally
The fetters that arise dependent on the: The fetter that arises dependent on the eye and sights
The fetter that arises dependent on the ear and sounds
The fetter that arises dependent on the nose and smells
The fetter that arises dependent on the tongue and tastes
The fetter that arises dependent on the body and touches
The fetter that arises dependent on the mind and thoughts
The understanding of the fetters [mn10:4: Understanding how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise
Understanding how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned
Understanding how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future
The meditation practice (a repetitive se: Meditate observing an aspect of principles internally
The understanding of the awakening facto: Understanding how the awakening factor that has not arisen comes to arise
Understanding how the awakening factor that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development
The meditation practice (a repetitive se: Meditate observing an aspect of principles internally
Meditate observing an aspect of principles externally
Meditate observing an aspect of principles both internally and externally
Meditate observing the principles as liable to originate
Meditate observing the principles as liable to vanish
Meditate observing the principles as liable to both originate and vanish
Mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness
Meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
The four noble truths [mn10:47.4]: This is the origin of suffering
This is the cessation of suffering
This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering
The purpose of the four kinds of mindful: To get past sorrow and crying
To make an end of pain and sadness
To end the cycle of suffering
